bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 40 (Wednesday, March 8, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BEN RAY LUJAN of New Mexico:H.R. 1439.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8.[Page H1949]

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Communications and Technology.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

Keeping Our Campaigns Honest Act of 2017

This bill directs the Federal Communications Commission to revise its sponsorship identification rules to require the disclosure announcements required for broadcast matter or origination cablecasting matter that is political or that involves the discussion of a controversial issue of public importance to include the names of significant donors to the person whose identity is required to be disclosed in such an announcement.
item.name: Introduced in House

bill.title: Keeping Our Campaigns Honest Act of 2017

item.title: To direct the Federal Communications Commission to revise its sponsorship identification rules so as to require the disclosure of the names of significant donors to persons paying for or furnishing broadcast matter or origination cablecasting matter that is political matter or matter involving the discussion of a controversial issue of public importance.
Keeping Our Campaigns Honest Act of 2017
Keeping Our Campaigns Honest Act of 2017

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Communications and Technology.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
